chapter.htmlStringContent:
There are multiple possible physical, metabolic, cognitive, and psychological complications following head injury, which may impact on a person's ability to function and return to normal activities. Head injury is the commonest cause of death and disability in people aged 1–40 years in the UK [NICE, 2014c]. Up to half of all adult inpatients with a head injury experience longterm psychological and/or physical disability [SIGN, 2009].

  • Concussion — refers to a disturbance in the function of the brain caused by a direct or indirect force to the head. It typically results in the rapid onset of short-lived impairment, which resolves spontaneously [SIGN, 2009].
  • Post-concussion syndrome — this may include multiple physical symptoms such as headaches, dizziness, nausea, balance and co-ordination problems, changes in appetite, sleep, vision, and hearing; and cognitive and behavioural symptoms such as fatigue, anxiety, depression, irritability; problems with memory, concentration, and decision-making [Mott et al, 2012].
    • A systematic review of concussion in various contact sports found the incidence of concussion ranged from 0.18 to 3.6 per 1000 athlete exposures for non-professional sports people [Tommasone and Valovich McLeod, 2006].
  • Intracranial haemorrhage
    • The incidence of intracranial haemorrhage in a person with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15 has been estimated at 1 in 3,615 [SIGN, 2009]. The risk is increased in people taking anticoagulant medication [Nishijima et al, 2012].
  • Open or depressed skull fracture; basal skull fracture.
  • Seizures.
  • Problems with gait, mobility, muscle weakness, spasticity, and contractures [SIGN, 2013].
  • Communication and swallowing problems (may include dysarthria, dysphasia, and other difficulties in the use of language) [SIGN, 2013].
  • Hypopituitarism (particularly following moderate or severe brain injury) [Zaben et al, 2013]
    • Hypopituitarism is estimated to occur in 33–50% of all people following traumatic brain injury, and may be caused by haemorrhage, raised intracranial pressure, oedema, skull fracture, or direct insult to the pituitary gland.
    • Symptoms are often non-specific and overlap with post-concussion symptoms. Rare life-threatening complications include sodium dysregulation and adrenal crisis.
  • Depression and anxiety
    • A large single cohort study (n = 559) found that 53.1% of people met the criteria for depression at some point in the year post-injury, and the prevalence of depression was eight times the rate in the general population [Bombardier et al, 2010].
    • A meta-analysis of 41 studies of the prevalence of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) in adults following non-penetrating traumatic brain injury found 11% of people were diagnosed with GAD (range 2–28%), and cases were most prevalent 2–5 years post-injury [Osborn et al, 2016].
  • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
    • An observational study (n = 96) found that 27.1% of people with a severe traumatic brain injury developed PTSD six months after the initial injury [Bryant et al, 2000].
    • PTSD can occur after severe head injury even if there is no recollection after the traumatic event (if the person has extended post-traumatic amnesia) [Schwarzbold et al, 2008].
  • Cognitive impairments — may include problems with memory, attention and concentration, planning, problem-solving, language, and perception [SIGN, 2013].
  • Challenging behaviour — this may include inappropriate vocalisation, disinhibited or sexualized behaviour [SIGN, 2013].
  • Death
    • The case fatality rate following head injury is low, but trauma is the leading cause of death in people under the age of 45 years, and up to 50% of these cases are due to a head injury [SIGN, 2009].
    • About 0.2% of all people attending emergency departments with a head injury die as a result. The majority of deaths are in people who present with a moderately or severely impaired consciousness level [NICE, 2014c].
    • A UK prospective survey of case notes of children aged less than 15 years who were admitted to hospital (n = 5700) found that the mortality rate from childhood head injury was 0.4% [Trefan et al, 2015].

[SIGN, 2009; SIGN, 2013; NICE, 2014c]
